characters: INSIDE THE BACK OF THE HUMVEE --
AT THE END OF THE TUNNEL
AT THE END OF THE ALLEY -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men and women standing, looking up. Sad and hopeless. The middle-aged faces bathed in the pale light of the televis they are silently watching.

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE
dialogues.text: Baby Diego was killed in a bar fight in Buenos Aires after refusing to sign an autograph... A man enters the coffee shop, making his way through the people: THEO FARON (55). Detached, unkempt, scruffy beard glasses, Theo is a veteran of hopelessness. He gave up before the world did.

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE
dialogues.text: He was born in 2005, the son of Marcello and Sandra Ricardo, a working class couple from Buenos Aires.... Theo wedges his way to the counter. He orders:

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Coffee. Black. Next to him, a 50-year-old woman stares up at the TV, cradling a small dog, tears rolling down her face. Theo waits, glancing at the old plasma TV without much interes ON TV: The face of “Baby” DIEGO (18), the most famous boy the world, a fair-haired teenager who has never lacked anything, smiling a practiced smile.

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE
dialogues.text: Baby Diego struggled his entire life with the celebrity status thrust upon him by being the world’s youngest person. ON TV: Stock footage of Diego's life. His baby portrait.. video footage of Diego learning to walk... Diego (8), at first communion... Diego (14), ambushed by paparazzi... (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE -
dialogues.text: Different accounts suggest that Diego spat in the face of a Zed who asked for an autograph, which began the fight that ended in his death. The Zed was lynched by the angry crowd shortly thereafter. Theo's coffee arrives. He lays exact change on the counte and starts to make his way out. Passing through the crowd Other people crying. Two grizzled POLICEMEN sip coffee, watching the news.

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE
dialogues.text: Diego, the youngest person on earth, was 18 years, 4 months, 2 days, 16 hours and 8 minutes old. Theo leaves the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo walks out with his coffee, facing the day. People walking along quietly, bundled up. Some with dogs. It’s cold. It’s wet. It’s sad. It’s London. SUPER: LONDON, 2024 A.D. A short distance from the cafe, Theo sets his coffee cup a post box. Slow traffic rolls past. Mostly “old” cars, ‘ models, some older. A couple of ‘18's. Motorized rickshaw scoot around the edges. A double decker bus passes with metal mesh on the windows. Bicycles. A billboard, showing a stern-faced leader flanked by the idealized profiles soldiers and policemen: “KEEPING ENGLA ALIVE”. Surveillance cameras on lamp posts and building sides with tiny disclaimers: “For Your Protection.” Theo takes out a flask from his pocket, unscrews the top, about to pour it into his coffee, when behind him -- KA-BOOM! A BOMB EXPLODES inside the cafe, blowing out the windows, rocking the ground. Theo reels with the blast, knocked off balance... Smoke pours through the shattered facade of the cafe. Wai of PAIN, as people stagger out, covered in residue, holdi their wounds, bleeding. A woman missing an arm. Theo regains his balance, shell-shocked, holding his ears FADE TO BLACK. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE: “THE CHILDREN OF MEN”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a train window covered by steel mesh, a billboard passing by: “GIVE HUMANITY A HAND - GET A FERTILITY TEST” Theo rubs his ringing ears, watching the desolate green landscape. POCK! POCK! Projectiles smack against side of the train, the steel mesh protecting the windows. Theo looks: A gang is hurling rocks and bottles. 20-year-old males, s with painted faces -- these are ZEDS. The youngest generation on earth, nothing to lose, it all ends with th After throwing their load, the Zeds recede, disappearing behind a billboard: “IS YOUR NEIGHBOR A TERRORIST? REPORT ALL SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY.”

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Fucking Zeds. Hurl a few rocks, crawl back into their cracks. Theo looks back to the train. Two middle-aged COPS face h on the opposite seat, commuting home after a long day. cOP 1 It’s our fault. We indulged the whiney pricks for too long. The last generation. End of the line. Big deal. (gestures to Cop 2) Rick’s boy, he’s what, 20? He got dealt the same hand. He didn’t quit. Good boy, that Scottie. Joined the force, what, a year ago?

dialogues.speaker: COP 2
dialogues.text: Uh huh. Cop 2 fumbles with something in his hand: a strip of pill

dialogues.speaker: COP 1
dialogues.text: Two weeks ago, he and some other rookies walked into a Zed ambush. A real zedding. Outnumbered, two to one, three to one -- hell, seven to one! When we got there later, the floor was covered with blood. Blood and teeth. Zed’s teeth. And the rookies...not a bloody scratch. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: cop 1 (CONT'D) They pummelled the pissant Zeds. You could almost feel sorry for them. Those zeds have numbers, but no discipline, no technique. And more important, no pride.

dialogues.speaker: COP 2
dialogues.text: Yeh. Cop 2 pops one of the pills into his mouth. cop 1 Pride. That’s what set us apart. That’s why England’s still alive. Look at the rest of the world. It’s hell out there. Theo looks out the window. Graffiti on a wall: “LAST PERS TO DIE PLEASE TURN OFF THE LIGHTS”.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo steps off the train. Policemen patrol the platform, some with German Shepherds. He looks around, spotting an older man across the way. He walks toward him.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Hey, amigo. JASPER PALMER was young in the 60’s, and has refused to l go of his youth ever since. Thick glasses, wispy beard, l hair, he is probably the coolest 75-year-old on the plane

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Hi, Jasper. The two old friends greet each other warmly.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: How's it going?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Quite groovy. Quite, quite groovy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abandoned fields with ruined farms, exhausted barns that like scarecrows. A car crosses, its headlights cutting through the darkeni blue, passing machinery rusting on the fallow land. A Vol sedan, circa 2009, not mint but still reliable.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Many get killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘ THEO (OFF) I don’t know. Fuck, the place was packed.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Who set the bomb?

dialogues.speaker: THEO, (OFF)
dialogues.text: Fuck knows. My ears are stiJ.l ringing.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (OFF)
dialogues.text: You mean the “eeeeeee”? INT. JASPER’S CAR - DRIVING -- CONTINUOUS Jasper watching his mirrors, navigating the sparse road. Theo in the front seat, massaging his ears. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: (continues) «+. "eeceecece”?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Ub huh.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: You know, pigs are planting most of them. Then they blame Foogies, the 5 Fishes, or whoever they want.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Right after it went off, there were some wounded, crawling out. A bloody woman, holding the hind of a dog. And the people on the street, walking by.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I left.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: I’m glad they missed you, amigo. Losing you and Baby Diego on the same day would be too much grief to bear. (off Theo’s look) You did hear about Baby Diego.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You kidding me? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: They say he was completely wasted.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Baby Diego was always wasted.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: He was a wanker.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he was the youngest wanker on the planet.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Quite true. Quite, quite true. Theo smiles. The headlights illuminate a wooded area.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Volvo slows down, and makes a left turn, going off th road, stopping in front the woods. Jasper and Theo get out. Jasper walks to the middle of th empty road, looking both ways.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: (starting a joke) So there‘s this supper. Scientists and wise men, you know, Human Project, that sort of bullocks.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (rolling with it) Yeah... Assured the coast is clear, Jasper walks toward a row of bushes in front of the trees, illuminated by the headligh

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: They‘re throwing around theories about the ultimate question: how is it that human beings haven‘t had babies in 18 years? Theo walking with Jasper toward the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: The biologist blames genetic experiments that altered DNA. The environmentalist says that pollution and bio-experiments poisoned the water. You know, the typical jada jada. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jasper removes one of the bushes -- it’s not rooted.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: A New Age bloke claims Mama Nature is merely protecting herself. Theo removes another bush. This is a false hedge, hiding tiny dirt path behind it.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Then they all look at this English scientist, who hasn‘t said a word, he just keeps eating. Jasper stops Theo.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: They ask him, “So, what do you think? Why don’t people have babies anymore?” The English bloke looks at them, he’s chewing on a wing... (thick English accent) “I haven't a clue,” he says. “But this stork is quite lovely, isn’t it?” Jasper playfully hits Theo.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Waaah! You get it -- he’s eating a stork!

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (smiles) Stork. That’s funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through the woods, Jasper’s car crossing the dirt path, t headlights on.

dialogues.speaker: THEO, (OFF)
dialogues.text: How's Janice?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She’s lovely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jasper navigates the dirt path carefully.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: (sighs) Tends to wander off occasionally. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I found her last week on the other side of the brook. Mud all over her nightgown, . shivering a death of cold, poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I’m sorry.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: When she’s her normal self, she’s been mentioning it. Quietus.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Quietus?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: She feels worthless. She feels a burden to me. When she’s lucid, she remembers what we used to be. Through the windshield, in a clearing in the trees, visib in the last light of day: a low-tech, jury-rigged eco-hou complete with primitive solar panels and a grass roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Stones’ "Ruby Tuesday” plays. JANICE (70) sits ina chair, staring ahead. She was young in the 60’s, and now old. The light is gone from her eyes, her face a blank ma

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Hi, Sweetie. Jasper kisses her. Janice does not react.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Theo’s here. He came for a little visit. Theo, remember? Your Rebel With a Lost Cause? Jasper motions Theo over.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Hi, Janice. No response from Janice. She is staring at a wall of phot Her lifetime frozen in images. A shrine to her past.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: She's not always like this. She’s in and out. INT. JASPER’S KITCHEN -- NIGHT Jasper and Theo at the kitchen table, eating vegetable so (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: A couple weeks ago, I came on this Dutch bloke, lost out back in the woods. Poor soul, wasn’t much left of him. Remember the pictures of those starving wretches in Ethiopia? Same thing, only blond. He said he‘’d escaped from Bexhill. They dug a tunnel under the fence and came over, 200 of them. Mostly French, Spaniards... (emphasis for Theo) ...a few Americans. They were crossing no man’s land. Soldiers caught them. Lined them up, shot them down. 200 hundred refugees. Unarmed. Bam. Just like that. Keeping England Alive. It didn’t make the news.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Not surprising.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Somehow this bloke escaped, got through no man’s land, got over that hill. I gave him some food. Amigo, he told me some spooky stories about what’s happening in Europe. Atrocities you'd never believe. And the look in his eyes. Jasper eats a spoonful of soup, looking at Theo.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: It’s sick. What humans can do to each other. Theo ponders a potato.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: I offered to hide him. He refused. Said he had to get to London. Said he had friends there. He left. All the way to London, no papers.

dialogues.speaker: . THEO
dialogues.text: He won‘’t make it.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: I know. They both eat a spoonful of soup.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: But I’d like to think he would.  10. INT. JASPER’S GREENHOUSE -- NIGHT A make-shift affair, grow lights coaxing marijuana plants into bloom. Theo and Jasper chill, Jasper rolling a joint

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Business has been slow. Daddy government gives pills and anti-depressants as part of your ration... (shows joint) +.-and the Buddha is still illegal! Most of my weed now goes to Bexhill. A bloke buys it from me and smuggles it over. Guess what he does. His real job.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Border cop.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: Bravo. He smuggles it through no-man’s land. Jasper fires a joint.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: (offers Theo a hit) Want some? Theo shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Jasper, you’re taking the whole thing too personally. In 80 years, humanity will disappear. So what? Ninety-eight percent of the species that roamed around earth have gone extinct. Jasper takes another hit. Theo nods.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: The dinosaurs had a pretty good run of it. Now it’s our turn. What would we be so damn special? Just because we left behind a few interesting piles of rocks?

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: And some books. Some really awesome books. And those really smashing symphonies. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ll.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Dylan. The two men smile and fall quiet.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: We made a bullocks of the whole thing, didn’t we? Maybe God is ready for a little peace and quiet. INT. JASPER’S HOUSE -- NIGHT Janice still staring at the wall. Theo comes to her. He takes the hair brush she is holding. And begins brushing long gray hair. Among the photos on the wall, one taken at a demonstratio catches Theo’s attention: a younger Janice and Jasper, locking arms with Theo, defiant and long-haired, and a yo woman with the same attitude. Theo carries a 2-year-old b in a baby backpack. A placard for “Global Democracy” can read behind them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Through a window, we see identical functional apartment buildings on a foggy morning. Next to the window: an old plasma wide-screen TV displays the time. A digit changes -- 8:30. The TV turns on. ON TV: A woman reads the morning news. War torn streets. Militia’s marching. Citizens watching fearfully out their windows. A 50-year-old soldier in fatigues and beret, a Dixie flag flying behind, gives a speech to a crowd in fr of the ruined facade of Camden Yards.

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE
dialogues.text: ...the American city of Baltimore fell to the Southern Alliance after months of furious street battles. It is seen as the biggest setback to the national government since the invasion of Northern California by the Oregon Alliance. The national government in D.C. has steadily lost popular support since its bombing of Cincinnati seven years ago in an attempt to eradicate militia strongholds. Reflected in the window: CLICK! a light on a side table g on. A form gets up slowly, sitting up on a bed... it’s Th shaking out the cobwebs, his head foggier than London.  12. EXT. STREET’ -- DAY Seven people, men and women, standing with their hands up against a brick wall. Police dogs growl and sniff at thei heels. Policemen linger behind them.

dialogues.speaker: THEO, (OFF)
dialogues.text: All the past historical events, the so- called facts, flow to one point... Theo walks past. He’s dressed for the day in a worn tweed jacket, a leather pack strapped over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: THEO, (OFF)
dialogues.text: (continues) .+-which we call the present.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo enters a gate fringed with barbed wire.

dialogues.speaker: THEO, (OFF)
dialogues.text: (continues ) And then there are all the events which have yet to occur... Not the grand hails of Oxford, rather, a cluster of one- storey concrete buildings, circa 2000.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: {continues ) +--the future.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A security machine swallows his leather case as Theo stan with his arms spread, a Guard frisking him.

dialogues.speaker: THEO, (OFF)
dialogues.text: (continues ) The moment where the past and the future meet is the tip of both cones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo, somewhat animated, draws two “V” cones on a black board, the tips touching each other.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (continues ) This tip is not only a moment. It’s a perception, and there are as many perceptions as people on this planet. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Theo faces the sizeable lecture room, three quarters empt Students stare back at him blankly. People in sleeping ba in back. A man snores in the front row, his pants wet, th urine dripping to the floor.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Any questions?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SIRENS, screaming from police cars, racing by, disappeari into the distance. Theo walks on the sidewalk. A billboard, soothing graphic blue on blue: “QUIETUS -~- you can find relief.” The sidewalk strewn with trash, lethargic breeze. A young couple, embracing, kissing in the open. Theo walks by, leather case over his shoulder. He’s holdi a book, reading as he walks: “Salem’s Lot” by Stephen Kin The young couple breaks their embrace. They begin to foll Theo from behind. He does not notice, reading about a boy who got himself locked inside a vampire’s room. The couple follows, pulling ski masks over their heads. As Theo approaches the corner, a van appears on the stree skidding to a stop, blocking his path. He slows down... A motorcycle comes from behind, skidding to a stop, block his street side. Theo pauses, confused -- The ski masked couple upon him, he pulling out a burlap s she pulling out a pistol. And the van door slides open, showing a masked man holdin semi-automatic gun. Theo reacts, backing away -- The woman sticks the gun into his ribs, whispering an ord

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Quiet. The burlap sack comes over Theo's head. She shoves him through the van door. The motorcycle revs, ready to go. The man hops on behind. The woman jumps into the van, the door slides shut. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The motorcycle peels off in one direction. The van tears off the other way. INT. KIDNAPPER’S ROOM -- DAY Blackness.

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: Not so tight...bring some water... put your hood on... The burlap sack comes off. Newspapers glued on the walls, covering them over. Theo is cuffed to a chair. A light shines in his face. A Tall Man in a mask holding it.

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN, (LUKE)
dialogues.text: You are under the jurisdiction of the 5 Fishes. Your basic human rights will be respected. You will be expected to keep this encounter confidential. To ensure this, you will be under constant surveillance, as you have been for the last two months. The 5 Fishes have eyes everywhere. Do you need water? Theo nods, cotton-mouth.

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN, (LUKE)
dialogues.text: Water.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Are the handcuffs necessary?

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN, (LUKE)
dialogues.text: Unfortunately, yes.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: (an order) Uncuff him.

dialogues.speaker: TALL MAN, (LUKE)
dialogues.text: I‘don't think --

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN'S VOICE
dialogues.text: Do it. The Tall Man gestures. A Short Man (PATRIC) goes behind T and begins unfastening the cuffs. Another hooded man give him a glass of water. A woman in a mask approaches, walking with a limp. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: “The only reason to breathe is to make a difference.” Theo reacts, taken aback. The woman sits down, facing him

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Those are your words, remember? “The only reason to breathe is to make a difference.”

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You want to know the truth? I got that from a Chinese fortune cookie. The woman takes the mask off. JULIAN TAYLOR is Theo’s age and although life has taken a harder toll on her, she sti radiates the beauty of someone who believes. A scar runs along the side of her face. Theo is stunned. He recovers with a smirk.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Not bad for somebody whose been dead for six years. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (to the others) I met Theo when we were 20, during an anti-globalization demonstration in Seattle. He was a man of ideals, dreadlocks and hemp. We locked eyes while chanting “WIO OUT”. Julian locks eyes with Theo.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (chanting) “WTO OUT! WTO OUT!” And by time the police attacked, we were making out. We kissed as the tears ran down our faces from the tear gas. We fell in love. We were going to change the world -- our love was going to change the world. You know, the John and Yoko bug. Though Julian addresses the half dozen people in the room her eyes on Theo. They are the only two without hoods. He checks his coat. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ‘ THEO Can I have my flask?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Theo was pissed that all the money for health and education was going to army contractors. So he had this idea. We would chain ourselves to the sculpture in front of the Boeing corporate headquarters. Naked.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Naked was your idea.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: We got shy, stopped at our underwear, thank god, and we chained ourselves to the sculpture. And we threw away the key. Full commitment. Now we're waiting for the employees to show up. Waiting for the TV cameras to show up. And it’s cold. And nobody is showing up. It gets colder. So we start yelling. “Hello? Help?” I mean, where’s a surveillance camera when you need one? It’s getting even colder. Finally, a patrol car comes. The cops get out, they're looking at us. We‘re chained, we’re shivering, we're in our underwear. Julian and Theo looking at each other, reliving this mome

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (laughing) Cops says, “What are you doing?” And you say, “Protesting.” Cop says, “Come back tomorrow.” And I said, “Why?” Cop says--

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: “It’s Columbus Day.”

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. They smile, looking at each other. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Is this why I’m here? To reminisce about the good old days?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I need your help. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Can I have my flask?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They’re in some sort of basement room with no windows. Th sips his flask. Julian smokes a cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Death suits you.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (smiles) You get used to it. They made a big deal about it in the papers, didn’t they? That unfortunate gas explosion.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (recalling) Uh huh.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: My stove was electric. -

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: There was a body.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: When the bomb exploded, it blew me down the stairs. But there was Algerian refugee staying at my flat. Fatima. That’s the charcoal they found. Poor thing.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (pissed) You could have called. You could have told me.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: What was the point?

dialogues.speaker: TREO
dialogues.text: It’s courtesy.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. The only way for me to stay alive was to stay dead. Theo looks at Julian with tenderness.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: And the limp... was that the...explosion? (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: The scar was the explosion. The limp is from prison. {points to her left ear) And the hearing loss. And the nightmares.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Ahuh...

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Eight years. Isle of Skye. Julian stubs out her cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You always got off on martyrdom.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I need an exit visa, Theo. (off his look) Not for me. There’s a girl we need to get out of the country. If they find her, they will kill her.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: What’d she do?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: I'm not allowed to go into detail. But you have to trust me. You have to do this.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: There’s nothing I can do.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Teddy Phillips offered you a position with the Noah Project three years ago. He’s the Minister of Culture.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: It’s a bullshit project, a million people starving to death in Madrid, and we march in and save the Goyas --

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: That’s not the point. He can get you a visa. He’s your friend. You never asked your friends for help. Julian looks at Theo. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: This girl is in trouble, Theo, and we can help her.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I kicked idealism.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: She’s 21. Twenty-one. This lands with Theo. Julian knows it -- she expected it.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Dylan would have been her age.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: That‘s low.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: That’s how strongly I feel. I never asked you for anything before, did I? Off Theo, knowing that she hasn't.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Theo in back facing the rear, blindfolded. PATRIC (25) dr ~- Irish, dreadlocks, committed. Facing Theo is LUKE (45) moral authority, practiced compassion, unwavering certain

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You understand that disclosing Julian’s identity would put her in extreme jeopardy. Quite frankly, everyone opposed her taking this risk.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: She’s stubborn.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: She‘s a true believer.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You’re Luke Grissom, right? (no response) The priest. I met you before. At that London thing. Silence. The two men remembering London.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: The London massacre unleashed so many demons. Not only the military coup. The famine, the Zed event... Theo remains quiet. LUKE ; I’m sorry about what happened to you. I can’t imagine that kind of loss. Luke pulls on his ski mask. The van slows down. Patric pulls on his mask.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (to Theo) You may take off your blindfold. Theo pulls off his blindfold, blinking with the sudden li Luke hands him a piece of paper and a coin.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Call this number if you need to contact us. The token is for the bus. The van stops. The door slides opens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo steps out of the van at a bus stop. A billboard show young couple tenderly holding a creature which looks impossibly similar to a baby. A doll. A slogan: “LOVE IS WHAT YOU GIVE.” In smaller print: “Now with body temperat and breathing motion.”

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: This mission is a good deed. I don’t need to tell you that Julian is only involved with good deeds. The door slides shut as the van drives off, leaving Theo the midst of a dozen lingering prostitutes, oblivious to security cameras rigged on the bus stop, a few tiny pooch tapping around. A double-decker with steel meshed windows coming down the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Rolis Royce passing through a heavily guarded restricte gate, leading into the pristine London Mall.  21. INT. ROLLS ROYCE - DRIVING -- Day A uniformed chauffeur drives, Theo in back, now dressed i worn-out suit, looking out the window: On the London Mall, well-dressed citizens on their aftern outing, some walking their dogs, which are dressed in matching outfits. Some dressed in chaps, riding horses. T privileged minority. A restricted zone.

dialogues.speaker: SOUTHWARK BRIDGE CHECK POINT
dialogues.text: The chauffeur stops at a security gate at the entrance to Southwark bridge. He hands papers to a Security Officer. Guards check under the car with mirrors. Dogs sniff for bombs. They are waved through.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coming over the bridge: an imposing brick structure, its square tower dominating the gloomy sky: the modern Tate Museum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Rolls Royce parks, a security guard opening the door. Theo gets out. Dogs sniff at him, surveillance cameras training over. A government official comes to meet him, extending his hand, smiling. Theo mumbles something. The official explodes with a forced laugh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo crosses through a body scanner. A screen outlines hi skeleton and solid objects, zipper, coins, his flask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Official leads Theo through a hall hung with painting arriving at a door, leaving him there, walking away. Theo enters...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo is awed. In the middle of the marble hall, under the soft glow of a skylight dome, standing alone, in its perfection, inviting, Michelangelo's David. ‘The real thi Theo is drawn to the sculpture -- WOOF! Two Irish Mastiffs laying on the floor in front of David. Theo doesn’t speak dog, but knows that means stop. Deep growls, the Mastiffs sit up. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: From behind the David, a man appears, THEODORE “Teddy” PHILLIPS. Around Theo’s age, but looking younger, Teddy i dressed in T-shirt and jeans. The fragile enthusiasm of someone who found an external reason to hold on.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: We couldn’t save “La Pieta’”. It was already smashed by the time we got there. But this is rummy, eh?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: My Mom had a plastic one in the bathroom. It was a lamp. Teddy approaches Theo.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Hey, bro. Teddy and Theo embrace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An endless corridor, hung with masterpieces on both walls Teddy throws a tennis ball down the corridor, the Mastiff chase after it, shrinking in the distance. Teddy and Theo carry drinks. Rembrandt's self-portraits a as they pass.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: +-.the self-portraits. Scattered around the world. Pain in the ass putting them together. We have most of them. We lost the one at the Frick. That thing in New York was a real blow to art.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Not to mention people.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: This one blows my mind. His last one. He stops in front of Rembrandt’s final self-portrait.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Look at him. An old Dutch bloke. Filled with remorse. He’s saying something. Can you tell what he’s saying? Theo looks at the portrait. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: “Oh, well...”

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Exactly. This bloke did some of the wickedest masterpieces in human history, and here he is. At the end of his days. Looking at you. Regretful, mischievous... “Oh, well.” An old Rembrandt looks down at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Planes drop bombs on civilians. Black and white cubist mayhem. Theo and Teddy stand in front of Picasso’s “Guernica”. The real thing. The Mastiffs sit nearby.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: I sent you some tasty French wine for your birthday, I hope you got it --

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Yeah, I meant to call. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: How are you doing, bro?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Not so well. I think I need to change course. Try something different.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: I must say, I was astounded you were still interested.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You gotta admit, it’s kind of kinky.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Wasting precious social resources to assemble an art collection that will be enjoyed by no one.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Trading guns for art.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Noticias, bro. Latin America se acabé. Italy finito. France c’est fini. Germany kaput. Sayonara Japan. Bye, bye America. We used to try to save the world, but it was too late. (MORE) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The world chose to save itself instead. We might as well save what made us great.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Ahun.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: You still don’t get it. Do you good to get you out of your cave, bro. Teddy looks at Theo -- silently acknowledging his friend’ rough time.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: We got the Hermitage, and saved most of the Reik. (beat) Paris is not going to hold. Quel dommage. They’re letting us have a peek at the Louvre before the looters get to it. You'll have to be quite selective.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: My Aunt had a Mona Lisa in her living room. Teddy smiles, gives Theo a friendly pat.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: It’s so rummy you're doing this, bro.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo and Teddy hang, drinking a bottle of 2004 Chateau Margeaux, looking down on London. The Thames flows by, St Paul’s shows off, the day prepares to end. Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I'll need a pair of exit visas.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: A pair?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: There’s this girl.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: Paris n’est plus la ville des amants. It's real hell down there.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I know, but you know. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: (smiles) You dog. Something serious?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: A couple of bruises. Teddy opens a small silver case. He takes out a pill, offering it to Theo, who shakes his head, staring at him.

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You amaze me. What keeps you going? In a hundred years, there won’t be one sad fuck left to remember you. What is it?

dialogues.speaker: TEDDY
dialogues.text: You really know what it is, bro? I just don’t think about it. Teddy pops the pill, washing it down with wine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE SCREEN: “A Hard Day's Night”. The four lads escapi from a hoard of fans...

dialogues.speaker: BEATLES
dialogues.text: (singing) “Can’t buy me love...” Theo pushes through a thick red curtain, entering the mos empty theatre. He walks down the aisle. He takes a seat. ON THE SCREEN: An empty treeless park, the lads frolickin gleefully, falling all over each other. Goofy abandon. A VOICE behind Theo:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Don’t turn around. Do you have it? Theo takes an envelope from his pocket, reaching it back

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Please put it under the seat. Theo puts the envelope under the seat. The man behind him takes it. It’s Luke. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: It’s a joint visa.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What does that mean?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: She’s my companion. She can only leave the country with me.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Why did you -~ ?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: It's what they gave me.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: So you’ll have to come.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I‘'m not going. Tell Julian I did what I could. Theo stands to leave.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What are we supposed to do?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Have a democratic assembly, or one of those things you guys like.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Faron -~

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I've seen the movie. I know how it ends. ON THE SCREEN: The lads‘ fun comes to an abrupt end when are confronted by a stern COP.

dialogues.speaker: COP
dialogues.text: (in the movie) Do you realize this is private property?

dialogues.speaker: RINGO
dialogues.text: (in the movie) Sorry, sorry...  27. INT. QUIETUS AUDITORIUM -- DaY Rolling clouds across a glorious blue sky, touched with colors of a gently fading sun, a glimpse of heaven. You almost don’t notice the pixels. Profiles of faces lying down on soft pads, staring at the clouds projected on the ceiling. Mostly older men and wom some middle-agers, and a few in their youth. Soothing mus suffuses the ambience, and a gentle female voice:

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Forgiveness. Experience forgiveness. Dwell in forgiveness. Forgiveness towards those who purposely caused you pain. Forgiveness. Forgiveness towards those who unwittingly caused you pain. Forgiveness. Forgiveness towards yourself. Forgiveness. Forgiveness. Dwell in forgiveness. The participants rest on the floor, as if entering a gent sleep. They are dying. It’s peaceful. It’s inviting. It’s Quietus. Attendants dressed in white gently administer to each participant. Holding them. Offering each a cup to drink from. After they have drunk, they are laid gently back do

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE
dialogues.text: A few dozen people arrayed on the bleacher seats. Some ar there to observe loved ones make their final passage. Oth are just looking for a warm place to sleep. Theo arrives, harried -- he has rushed to get there. He looks around the vast bleacher section, and finds: Jasper standing by the glass, looking below. Theo approac

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: She left a note. I didn’t get here in time. Theo stands next to him.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: They say it is a peaceful way to go. Though the window, they see: (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: BELOW
dialogues.text: An Attendant approaches Janice. Her face is not the blank mask of before -- her eyes are moist with profound awaren of the end. The Attendant holds up the cup. Janice reaches her hand towards it, shaking. The Attendant steadies her hand her hand around it. Janice drinks.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Gratitude. Immerse yourself in gratitude. Gratitude. Gratitude for those who brought you joy. Gratitude. Gratitude for those who brought you pain. Gratitude. Gratitude for your unique journey. Gratitude. Gratitude. Dwell in gratitude. Janice’s grip slips from the cup. Her entire body relaxes The Attendant gently lays her down on the soft pad.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE
dialogues.text: Jasper and Theo, watching.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: We had just moved to Paris. We didn’t have much, a mattress, a couch. We were doing really bad, with dough. That day, I got back early from the Sorbonne. And I saw her from the window, coming home, carrying flowers. There was this curtain that was our closet, and I hid behind it. Through the glass, behind them, a disturbance: An Old Man resists the cup offered to him, knocking it away. The lig on the main floor cut out.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: (continues ) And I watched her... She put the flowers in a drinking glass, and she sat on the sofa, looking at them. The lights go up on the main floor, everything returned t its state of peace. The Old Man lays completely still.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: (continues ) She was humming that “I love Paris in the springtime” song. Very softly. Lost in her reveries. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: JASPER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She stayed there, just like that. Looking at the flowers. For a long time. And you know what she was doing? She was picking her nose. She always did that when she thought nobody was watching her. Did you ever notice?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (lying) No.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: That’s what she did. She picked her nose... (shows his little finger) With her pinky. Jasper looks down at Janice.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: She’s gone.

dialogues.speaker: BELOW
dialogues.text: Janice stares up at the clouds rolling across the ceiling

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: There is a light. Experience the light. Dwell in the light. Repose in the light. The light is soothing. The light is comforting. The light is love. It’s a light that shines forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo waiting on a plastic couch in the simple white room. People at the counter, picking up paper bags that resembl sacks of flour. Jasper returns from the counter, holding a brown sack. Th stands to meet him.

dialogues.speaker: JASPER
dialogues.text: She's still warn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside, the street is quiet. Theo and Jasper walk. Jaspe stoic, is holding Janice’s bag of ashes. Suddenly -- Jasper breaks down. Crying. All of his 75 years now revealed, all at once an old man.  30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON TV: A couple walking through a beautiful park, carryin baby. Slow motion sentimentality.

dialogues.speaker: COMMERICIAL VOICE
dialogues.text: --.she has her daddy’s eyes, and her mommy’s smile. She cries when she’s hungry, she cries when she’s wet. Her skin is so smooth it warms your heart. ON TV: A closer look at the baby: beautiful eyes, beautif smile, smooth skin. But it’s still a doll.

dialogues.speaker: COMMERCIAL VOICE
dialogues.text: Love is what you give. Theo sitting in the bar, half-watching the tv, already dr Two men sit on either side of him: Patric and Luke.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You looked better with your masks on. Theo staring toward nothing. The two men looking at him i expectation. Finally:

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I’l1l do it.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Thank you. Luke slides a small paper across to Theo.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We have to leave tomorrow. Theo looks at the small paper: a TICKET to football match

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I don't like soccer.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We call it football. Luke and Patric start to leave.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Tell Julian I’1l take the girl to Paris. Then I’m done.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: The men are gone. Theo takes a long gulp from his pint, a returns his attention to the TV. ON TV, a surveillance camera image: A man walking alone d 4 remote narrow street illuminated by lights overhead. Fr the darkness on either side... a gang of Zeds emerge.

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE
dialogues.text: ++-a security camera capturing the shocking zedding of a 43-year-old man from Shoreditch by a gang of Zed hoodlums... The Zeds swarm over the man, who disappears under their onslaught. A moment later, the Zeds retreat back to the darkness. One Zed left behind, staggering, holding a woun

dialogues.speaker: TV VOICE
dialogues.text: +.-it’s not clear if the Zed was stabbed by the victim or by one of his own gang. The wounded Zed falls to his knees, beside the man who la motionless on the sidewalk, naked, picked clean. FADE OUT. The chant of English football...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: KICK! A cleated foot propels the ball into the air. Men fight their way to it. We're well into a hard-fought Engl football match. Players smeared in sweat and mud. Theo in his seat, watching the match, drinking a beer, ha of the dog. The stadium half filled, lethargic fans, some faces painted, some holding little dogs. The sections secured by barbed-wire fences, security cameras and polic everywhere. : Theo searchés around. An older man sits next to him. A middle-aged man on his other side. Both watching the game A Woman stands, blocking his view, her right hand a fist opens and shows: the “5 Fishes” logo drawn on her palm. T hand closes, as she walks away. Theo stands and follows her.  32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman walks through a tunnel, exiting the stadium. Sh 40, and hates football. Theo follows. On the wall, a billboard: “REPORT ANY SUSPICIOUS ACTIVITY.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The crowd roars a goal as the woman crosses the concrete plain. Theo follows, a few yards behind. The woman walks to a bus stop with a billboard: “KEEPING ENGLAND ALIVE - FERTILITY TESTS - YOUR OBLIGATION.” A dou decker about to leave. As the bus starts to move, she get on. Theo runs, catching up to the rear of the bus, jumping on through the back door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo has just climbed inside, and he’s out of breath. The woman is going up the stairs. Theo follows. Theo emerges on the upper deck. The woman sits at the fro An overhead security camera keeping vigil. He sits down heavily in the first seat he sees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The double-decker rolls though a suburban area, the outsk of London. Very few people. Shuttered stores. Abandoned homes . A billboard: “KEEPING ENGLAND ALIVE ~ DENOUNCE ILLEGAL IMMIGRANTS - IT’S YOUR COUNTRY”.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: Through the metal meshed windows, the suburbs roll past. woman sits in front, staring ahead. Theo in his seat, trying not to doze off. The woman gets up. As she walks down the stairs, the briefest eye contact -- it springs Theo up to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the bus as rolls away, the woman walks across the stre (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Theo stands at the empty bus stop, looking at her. She stands on the other side, looking away. Theo waits. A few dogs sniffing around. A billboard showing a smiling woman looking at the sky at two-tone pill called “BLISS” The slogan: “JUST BE HAPPY.” smaller letters: “Now at kiosks”. RRRRR! The roar of an approaching motor... A motorcycle, appearing from down the street, skids to a in front of the woman. She hops on the back. RRRRR! The motorcycle tears away. Leaving Theo alone. Confused. The motorcycle roar recedin A FIAT MULTIPLA passenger wagon comes around the corner, heading toward Theo. It stops in front of him. The back door is opened. Theo looks inside: Luke at the wheel, Julian beside him. other women in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I didn’t know this was a family trip.

dialogues.speaker: LURE
dialogues.text: Please get in. Theo climbs in. As the door closes, the Multipla starts o

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Multipla pulling away. Theo accommodating himself, glancing at the woman seated beside him, in the middle se KEE (21) is dark-skinned, West Indies. When she was born, the world was already falling apart. She grew up knowing human life would not last much longer than her.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (to Julian) Is' this the girl?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Her name is Kee. Kee, this is Theo. Theo and Kee lock eyes.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: The fuck you watchin’ at? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Nothing. How you doing?

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Cheedo. “Kee looks away. Theo looks around the car.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: So this is the elite unit? MIRIAM (58), shy woman, Scottish, simply dressed, string bracelets. She can't believe it’s the end of the world. It’s not in the stars.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: This is Miriam and Luke.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We’re coming to Dover. To make sure you go away safely.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Cheers. Theo senses the tension in the car -- everyone is nervous

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Are we going to have a little sing-along? (no response) Good. I'm going to take a nap. Theo makes himself comfortable against the door and close his eyes, dozing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The roads of Canterbury are curvy, running through woods small hills. The Multipla cruises along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A hand reaches over, nudging Theo awake. JULIAN'’S VOICE Hey there. Theo’s eyes open.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: You were snoring.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: No I wasn’t.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (to the others) He always snored.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: She farted in bed. Julian smiles. Theo looks out the window at the wooded hi passing by, getting his bearings.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Where are we?

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Canterbury, believe it or not.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: No shit. Kee laughs at the small TV flipped down from the ceiling. ON TV: 70-year-old Mr. Bean kisses his teddy bear good-ni

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (to Kee) So what‘d you do?

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Why do you need to get out? Silence. Kee looks to Julian.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Come on, Jules. I need to know something. She's my travel buddy.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: {to Miriam) Why I gotta go with this bloke? Why can’t I go with you?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: You’ll be fine. (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: (to Theo) What do you know about the Human Project?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Julian, we're not supposed to --

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: We have to tell him sooner or later.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Iceland got scientists from all around the world. And the country fell apart. Like the rest of the world.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: That‘s what England wants you to believe, as a pretext to sever ties with them. It’s actually the last democracy on earth.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: The brightest minds in the world are there working together to find the cause of infertility.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: The scientists ate the stork. Blank stares.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Never mind. (to Kee) So, are you a scientist? Miriam spots something out the window.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: There... Through the windshield, up ahead: a BURNING CAR comes rol down a small hill, toward the road they’re travelling on. Luke accelerates, the Multipla responds grudgingly.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: ‘ LUKE We can make it. The Multipla picks up speed. The burning car careening do toward the road, but it looks like they may beat it...

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Gol! Luke slams the breaks, screeching to a stop, just avoidin

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: The flaming car cuts them off -- SMASH! -- crashing into derelict car.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MULTIPLA
dialogues.text: Tense silence. The road is now blocked by the flaming car

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: This is not good. They hear WAR CRIES.

dialogues.speaker: EMERGING FROM THE TREES
dialogues.text: ZEDS. A gang of 20ish males, faces painted, some masked, armed with stones, sticks and knives. A tribe of hunters descending down toward the road, in a wave, running at th

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MULTIPLA
dialogues.text: CRACK! The first stone hits the window.

dialogues.speaker: JULIAN
dialogues.text: Go around! Instead, Luke throws the car into reverse, screeching the backwards. The Zeds upon them, running down the car. CRAC Sticks and fists pounding, bodies piling on... Luke keeps pedal to metal, screaming in reverse, the last Zeds dropping off, giving chase, but can’t catch up...

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: A lone MOTORCYCLE comes from behind the burning car, two riders in masks, racing through the running Zeds, accelerating, towards the Multipla, coming closer...  38.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MULTIPLA
dialogues.text: Luke can't go any faster backwards, the motorcycle catche up, running alongside them. The Zed on back looks in the car, his eyes visible for an instant through his black ma Luke accelerates, and the motorcycle drops back, riding n in front of the car. Theo sees the Zed on back of the motorcycle rise up -- he aiming a high-powered RIFLE at them --

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: He’s got a gun -- BANG! The bullet crashes through the windshield -- Julian jolts with the impact, blood spraying. The passeng screaming in terror and disbelief:

dialogues.speaker: VOICES
dialogues.text: (in car) She’s hit! She’s hit!

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (screaming to Miriam) Cover her! Miriam uses her body to protect Kee. Theo is reaching ove the seat, coming to Julian. She’s been hit in the neck, she’s bleeding badly. Her eyes are open, alive, barely.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Cover the wound!

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Godammit, godammit!

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Cover the wound! Use your hand!

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: The motorcycle accelerates again, coming back alongside t

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MULTIPLA
dialogues.text: Theo sees the motorcycle approach, the Zed on back, point the gun at him, about to shoot. Abruptly, Theo throws open his door --  39.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: WHACK! Theo’s car door hits the motorcycle. The driver trying to keep balance, but he’s going too fast... The motorcycle careens and spills, throwing the gunman in the grass, the driver bouncing across the pavement, leavi lots of skin behind.

dialogues.speaker: INSIDE THE MULTIPLA
dialogues.text: Luke slows the car just enough to execute a turn, spinnin 180, heading away from the ambush, finally driving forwar

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: How is she? How’s Julian?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: She's bleeding, she’s bleeding a lot... Theo holds her throat wound with both hands, trying to da the blood with his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Hang on, Jules, hang on... Julian reaches toward her throat, grabbing one of Theo's hands. She squeezes the hand. Holding it tightly. Miriam rubs her palms together, laying healing hands onto Julian's head. Holding them there.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: She‘s making her transition. Theo still holding Julian’s wound and her hand. Miriam’s hands on her. Julian is dead. The car is silent. Then -- Approaching from the distance, they hear SIRENS.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Jesus . It’s a police caravan, two squad cars and a tactical van, coming from the opposite direction... Luke plays it cool, maintaining his speed, as the caravan heads right toward them... The Police caravan flies past them, headed for the scene the ambush. There's a moment of relief. until: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: In Luke’s rear-view mirror: one of the police vehicles br from the caravan, turning around, coming back toward them

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Jesus. Sirens screaming, the police car following, getting close Luke keeps driving.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Go, go, go, go, go!

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: You have to pull off. The Policemen are right on their tail. There’s no choice. Luke eases the car to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: The police car skids to a stop behind the Multipla. Immediately, two Policemen are out of their cars, approaching, guns drawn, screaming:

dialogues.speaker: COP 1
dialogues.text: Let’s see your hands!

dialogues.speaker: COP 2
dialogues.text: Your hands, let’s see your hands!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE MULTIPLA
dialogues.text: Luke watches the two Policemen approach.

dialogues.speaker: COP 2
dialogues.text: Out of the vehicle! Miriam opens her door, Theo opens his, starting to get ou

dialogues.speaker: ROAD
dialogues.text: Luke steps out his door, one hand raised in the air.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We were attacked by Zeds -- cop i Your hands! Luke pulls his other hand from the car -- BANG! Luke’s other hand is holding a gun, and he’s shot C through the heart. Before Cop 2 can react, Luke swivels - (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: BANG! Luke gets off another shot, taking down Cop 2. Cop fires off a shot -- BANG! Luke finishes Cop 2. The echo of gunfire dissipates. Theo standing there, taki it in. The two cops lay bleeding on the ground. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: The fuck?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Let's go.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (stunned) What did you do?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Let‘s go! Theo stays there, confused. Luke levels the gun at Theo.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Let’s go. Luke pointing the gun at Theo, who does not back down. He appears ready to finish with Theo -- and Miriam can tell.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Don't, Luke. (firmly to Theo) Get in. Now! Theo gets in the car. Luke gives the gun to Miriam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke driving away. All business, taking control.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We'll need a new car. We have to get off the main roads --

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You just killed two men.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We had no choice.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: No choice -- ? (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: He's right.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We'll need to find a safe house. I know Fishes in this zone. Miriam reaches forward, covering her hand over Julian’s e Theo looks at his bloody hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo holding Julian’s body by the arms and torso, draggin her uphill through the woods, Miriam helping with the fee They lay Julian's body between the trees. Miriam kneels beside her, praying a simple mantra. Using her palms to gently cover her eyes, her ears, her nose... Theo looks at Julian, then turns away, anguished at the s of her violent death. Trying to catch his breath. And the whole thing sinks in, the pain welling, overcoming him.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Fuck!

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: All is well. Theo turns to Miriam. She has tears in her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: She is dead.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: (with certainty) All is well. She died fulfilling her duty. Theo looks at Julian one more time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Whatever you choose to believe. Theo looks at Miriam, shakes his head, incredulous. Kee i waiting down the hill, next to the Multipla.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Luke is coming. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: HONK! HONK! An old Vauxhaul sedan parking on the roadside

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The empty, battered Multipla rolling downhill, picking up speed, flying off the road over a steep embankment -- CRASH! The Multipla smashes into the dense woods below. Disappearing into the foliage, metal crashing earth. Theo, Luke, Miriam and Kee stand on the road next to the English Vauxhaul, circa 2008. Theo pissed off, looking li hell, his shirt stained with Julian’s blood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: English rain ~~ steady, cold, bone-moistening. In the car silence. Miriam looking forward. The remnants of tears on Kee’s face. Theo sits in front, the wipers scraping shadows across hi exhausted face. He’s numb, staring at the black night ahe of him. Luke puts on the turn signal. Getting off the main road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Vauxhaul struggling up a muddy rutted road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Luke honks three times. Through the windshield, the headlights illuminate an old farm house. We see two men w outside the door. One of them holding a rifle.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Tom and Ian. They’re loyal fishes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Vauxhaul parks in front of the stone farm house. Luke turns the car off. The two men come to meet them. TOM (58), strong, dark featured, farmer, with wrinkles th come from working the earth. IAN (40), shorter, fine features, small town bureaucrat, the paleness of a man wh works with paper in fluorescent light. Tom holds a rifle, AR-45, the next generation. -

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Everything's been taken care of.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It‘'s an honor, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Hide the car, Tom. Don’t block it. We have to push start it.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: (re: Kee and Miriam) This is Kee, this is Miriam. They’1l need a place to wash up and rest. We need to convene.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: How bout Julian’s mate?

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: We’1l watch him.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: He needs a scrub. Get him a clean shirt. We'll send him back to London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo standing in front of the mirror after his shower. Th bathroom is small, dank, uncared for. Theo wipes the mist off the mirror, seeing himself. Reflected in the mirror, sees something on the wall behind him. He turns: AN OLD PHOTO. A weathered portrait from 30 years back, ta in front of the same farm house: a man, a woman... and th 5 children. All 5 kids hanging on a tire swing hung from large tree. A document from a world now gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo walking out of the bathroom wearing a fresh shirt. T is seated in a chair, waiting, holding his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Shirt fit?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: It’s fine, thanks.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: (proud) We've got an important meeting going on. Fishes from all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Beyond, through the door, Luke is gathered with 6 people haven't seen before.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Luke sent this for you. Tom hands him a bottle of whiskey. Theo accepts it with a smile -- the sad smile of someone aware of his condition.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You thank him for me. Theo heads for the door.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: If you're going out, take a coat. Catch a cold in this weather. Tom points to the coat rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rain has stopped. Theo, wearing a coat, standing outs the farm house, taking the first sip from the bottle. Tom pulling on his coat as he catches up, holding his rifle.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I'm in charge of watching you.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You're doing a good job, Tom. Theo offers him the bottle. Tom shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Alcohol is a tool of the government to numb the people. Theo takes another swallow.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: This your farm?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: House is mine. Consortium took the land and the cows. They pay me shite. Theo notices the old tree.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: That used to be a swing, right? A tire swing. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Yeh. A frayed rope dangles from a thick branch, moving with th breeze. A faint smile on Tom’s face, a memory.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Children’s stuff.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Yeah, children’s stuff. From a short distance, Miriam shouts to Theo:

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Faron, Kee would like a word with you. She’s in the barn. (to Tom) It’s okay, Tom. 1’11 watch him. Theo gives a nod to Tom, then starts walking toward Miria

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Mr. Faron.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: You talk funny. You’re from America?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: I‘m sorry about what happened there.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Thank you, Tom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo comes through the wooden door.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I’1l wait outside. Miriam closes the door. Theo is inside the old stone barn housing 40 cows and industrial milking equipment.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Faron?

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Theo turns: toward the end of the barn, Kee stands behind of the cows.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You want to talk to me? Theo starts walking toward her.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: You know they chop them cow’s tits? They do -- zzzzt. Fly, gone, bye. Only leave four. Four fits the machine. It’s whacko. Why not make machines that suck eight titties?

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: That’s what you want to talk about. Cows and titties?

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Julian told me ‘bout your baby. Theo looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Said it wasn't your fault.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Did she tell you I was carrying him?

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Said there was a lotta of families that day. Lotta kids. ‘Sposed to be a peaceful demonstration. And then the soldiers came. Theo shaking his head, not wanting to remember.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Said you blamed yourself, but nothin’ you could do, it wasn’t your fault.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: I was carrying him!

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Said the baby’s name was Dylan. This lands hard.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Said you gave up. Said you gave up ‘fore the world did. Said you carried his memory like a ball ‘n chain. Theo feels the shackles.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Dylan was Julian's baby too. Only she didn’t carry him like a ball ‘n chain. She carried him like a balloon. Julian’s words resonate.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Julian said anything go spooky, talk to him. Said I could trust you. Said you'd get me out of England.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Sorry, kid. It’s as far as I go. You've got friends, you’1l be all right. Nice chatting with you. Theo makes to leave.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: You can’t go. Kee begins to unbutton the front of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: You can’t leave me.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Don’t... The dress slips from her shoulder. She covers her breasts shyly. She is behind the cow, her chest bare. She is shivering. She looks at Theo.

dialogues.speaker: . KEE
dialogues.text: Got to help me. Theo wants no part of this.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (annoyed) Don't... Kee steps from behind the cow. Her arm covering her swoll breasts, her hand covering her panties. (CONTINUED )

Theo is frozen. The sight of her naked form. The curve of her hip. Her hair dangling over her shoulders. She’s staring straight into his eyes. Three million possibilities cross his mind in an instant, there is only one truth. Kee is pregnant. Instinctively, Theo extends his hand, walking toward her swollen belly. Kee allows it. Theo gently rests his hand on her belly. Impossibly stretched skin, holding new life.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: Oh. My. God. The door opens -- Luke enters the barn, followed by Ian and Miriam.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What‘s going on here? Kee immediately retreats, going behind the cow, covering herself up.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What is this? Miriam steps forward.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: She wanted him to know.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Nobody authorized it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: It's her body.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We're going to do what’s right. (beat) Meet inside in five minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo, Miriam and Kee walking to the farm house, Ian follo few steps behind. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: . THEO
dialogues.text: This is crazy. You know what this child means?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: We're very well aware of it.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You've been putting her at risk. She needs the best doctors --

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: I‘m a trained midwife.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: You were a midwife, twenty years ago. Who knows what could go wrong? She needs real doctors.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: That’s what we’re trying to give her.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: In France? You know what‘s going on in France?

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: France, wiffet. Iceland.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Kee may be the clue to cure infertility. The Human Project sent a boat.

dialogues.speaker: KEE
dialogues.text: Boat called “The Tomorrow.”

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: We were supposed to meet it in the channel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON Tv: slow motion, the Multipla coming in the opposite direction, the windshield blasted out. The image is blurr but Luke, Theo and Julian are recognizable. NEWSWOMAN‘’S VOICE The killers were identified as Luke Grissom, an ex-Catholic priest and one of the leaders of the 5 Fishes terrorist group. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: NEWSWOMAN’S VOICE (CONT'D) Julian Taylor, one of the founders of the terrorist group, who was thought to have died two years ago in a domestic accident. And Thelonios Faron, a history _ professor at King’s College, with terrorist links to Taylor. PHOTOS ON TV: Julian and Luke’s police mug shots. Theo’s King’s College ID. NEWSWOMAN’S The other passengers, two women, have not yet been identified. The TV goes off. Luke stands up.

dialogues.speaker: LURE
dialogues.text: This was national news, about an hour ago. He addresses an assembly of the 5 Fishes convened in the musty living room on sofas and chairs. Theo stands at the edge. He’s allowed to observe, but he cannot vote.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: This is the reality of the situation. Our identities have been disclosed. It’s too dangerous to proceed with the original plan. Kee squeezes Miriam‘s hand -- Miriam responds:

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: What about Iceland?

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We missed our chance.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: We can still make it through Bexhill --

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It’s too dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: (interrupts) Make it public. Theo’s uninvited opinion draws glares from around the roo

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Two years ago, another woman got pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The government took her away, under the pretext that one baby would bring false hope. They did experiments on her. Problem was, the best scientists were in Iceland. She miscarried. Then they killed her.

dialogues.speaker: THEO
dialogues.text: How do you know that?

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: The doctors involved were put in prison. I met one. Luke addresses the others.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: This pregnancy must remain secret. We'll drive North, to Glasgow. We have strong cells there. When the moment comes, this child will be our most powerful weapon to take the government down.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: Julian said this shouldn’t be about politics.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: It is about politics. Whoever controls this child controls destiny. That destiny doesn’t belong to Iceland. It belongs to England.

dialogues.speaker: FISHES
dialogues.text: Right... Absolutely... England.

dialogues.speaker: MIRIAM
dialogues.text: That was not the agreement.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: These are new circumstances. There is new leadership. I'm sure all Fishes will follow. This is Luke's moment -- he seizes it.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: We have been struggling to keep the flame of dignity alive. But it has been hard. Brothers and sisters, you know how hard it has been. (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: FISHES
dialogues.text: (grumbling) Yeah... that’s right...

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Some of us were killed. (looks sympathetically at Tom) Some of us lost loved ones. Tom nods. The Fishes are solemn.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: Some of us were beaten. Some of us were imprisoned. Some of us were tortured, humiliated. And right when we might have lost hope, when tyranny had stepped on us and nearly crushed us, when the flame was about to be extinguished...a torch appeared in the form of a child. And its fire will destroy tyranny. This child will be our new beginning. This child belongs to England. The Fishes have spoken.

dialogues.speaker: FISHES
dialogues.text: The Fishes have spoken! The Fishes look to Luke, unified -- they have found their leader.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farm is quiet. One light burns in the living room. To keeping guard at the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One Fish asleep in the single bed, another in the top bun bed, snoring. Theo lays in the lower bunk, wide awake, reeling, trying to make sense of all that has happened. He hears: the HUM of a small motor in the distance, getti closer. Then 3 tinny honks. Theo creeps out of bed, padding over to the window. Outsi A small motorcycle coming unsteadily up the rutted mud ro The driver is barely holding a dangling body, hardly able keep the motorcycle upright. The motorcycle arrives at the front door. Tom steps forwa

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Immediately, Luke comes out the door, accompanied by Ian, followed by two other Fishes. Luke gives an order: one Fi is sent back inside. Then two Fishes grab the unconscious man, carrying him toward the barn. Theo hears FOOTSTEPS. Somebody coming up the stairs. Theo moves quickly back to bed, making like he’s asleep. The door opens. Tom walks in. He gives a shove to the Fis sleeping in the single bed.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Come now. The sleeping Fish stirs.

dialogues.speaker: FISH 1
dialogues.text: Huh? What?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Luke wants us. It’s an alert. Tom’s legs cross in front of Theo, as he shakes the Fish the upper bunk.

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: It’s an alert.

dialogues.speaker: FISH 2
dialogues.text: Shite! What?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Quiet. Come now. Both Fishes climb out of their beds. They follow Tom out, closing the door. As soon as they leave, Theo opens his eyes. He gets out o bed, goes to the window, and sees: Luke, Ian and the motorcycle driver are walking toward th house. Luke is clearly agitated. Theo goes to the door and opens it: the hallway is empty. Tom and the others walking down the stairs. As soon as th disappear, Theo follows. He has no shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo coming down the stairs. He sees: Luke and Ian walkin in the house. He recognizes the motorcycle driver: It's Patric. Cut, bloody, clothes torn, soaked to the bon (CONTINUED )

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUED
dialogues.text: Ian addresses Fish 1 and Fish 2, who have just come from

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: Take the motorcycle to the barn.

dialogues.speaker: FISH 1
dialogues.text: Done. The Fishes head off.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Stay in extreme alert. (to Tom) You have any medicine?

dialogues.speaker: TOM
dialogues.text: Mostly for cows.

dialogues.speaker: IAN
dialogues.text: Hydrogen peroxide, bandages, clean towels, whatever you have, bring it to the barn. Tom disappears straightaway into the bathroom. Luke, Patr and Ian go to the kitchen. And close the door. Theo walks down the stairs, heading toward the back door. Tom walks from bathroom with an armful of medicines and supplies. No place to go, Theo leans back against he wall waiting for Tom to pass. Tom leaves by the front door. Th quietly walks to the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Theo comes out the back door... SQUISH! Theo's expression his socks are soaked in the cold mud. He sloshes quietly alongside the farm house, no coat, shivering in the cold. reaches kitchen window and sees: Luke pacing, Patric in a chair, Ian leaning on the table.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: What were you thinking? By whose orders? You realize you put the whole mission in jeopardy?

dialogues.speaker: PATRIC
dialogues.text: What was I supposed to do? You saw how he was! Bloody piece of pulp. And all the fuckin’ police coming. We had to hide in the woods. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: PATRIC, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, man, I don’t know what’s wrong, I think he’s all broken inside, I’m telling you, he needs a doctor.

dialogues.speaker: LUKE
dialogues.text: You shouldn‘t have come. It wasn’t authorized.

dialogues.speaker: PATRIC
dialogues.text: He’s my cousin!

dialogues.speaker: TAN
dialogues.text: Don’t worry, we're taking care of him. Theo has seen enough. He steps away from the window, sloshing back along the side of the house. Hearing the la fragment of conversation.

dialogues.speaker: PATRIC, (OFF)
dialogues.text: It’s that fucker’s fault, he opened the fucking door!

dialogues.speaker: LURE, (OFF)
dialogues.text: You sure nobody followed you?

dialogues.speaker: PATRIC
